title: Snacking on immature produce
vignette: May a farmer eat small amounts of produce while it is still ripening in the field before any tithes are taken?

options.text: Yes; casual field snacking is exempt until full ripeness.
No; all edible produce requires tithing first.

title: Domestic use vs. marketing
vignette: Does produce picked for home use require tithing sooner than produce earmarked for market sale?

options.text: Home use: tithe only after bringing inside; Market: tithe immediately.
Treat both the same—obligated at the moment of picking.

title: Eating an am-haʿaretz’s produce
vignette: A scrupulous ‘ḥaver’ is offered fruit by a neighbour of doubtful tithing habits. May he eat without separating tithes himself?

options.text: May eat—assume the host already tithed.
Must tithe again—personal obligation outweighs courtesy.

title: Worker’s right to eat while harvesting
vignette: A hired fig-picker wants to snack on the figs he is cutting. Is he allowed to eat untithed fruit on the job?

options.text: Yes; labourers may eat the produce they handle.
No; tithes must be taken before any eating.

title: Extending the perk to dependants
vignette: The same harvester sends his child to work instead; may the child snack untithed?

options.text: No; only the actual labourer enjoys the exemption.
Yes; the benefit follows the contract, not the person.

title: Crossing the property line
vignette: Once produce crosses into the employer’s enclosed yard, may the labourer still eat untithed fruit?

options.text: No; enclosure triggers the tithing obligation.
Yes; his eating right continues until final processing.

title: Transplanting vegetables and tithe reset
vignette: If a grower uproots vegetables and replants them elsewhere, must he tithe twice (before and after replanting)?

options.text: Yes; replanting creates a new obligation cycle.
No; once tithed, produce is discharged forever.

title: Selling to a non-observant buyer
vignette: May a farmer sell untithed produce to someone suspected of ignoring tithes?

options.text: Prohibited; seller must tithe first to prevent transgression.
Permitted; buyer bears his own religious duty.

title: Tithing duty on Syrian fields
vignette: Produce grown in Syria (annexed but outside biblical Israel): must tithes be separated before eating?

options.text: Yes; Syrian land is treated as Israel for tithes.
No; the obligation applies only in core Israel.

title: Worker’s snack-right when employer provides meals
vignette: Harvest laborers normally eat untithed produce while on the job. If the employer is contractually obliged to feed them cooked meals, do they still retain that field-snacking right?

options.text: Yes – the Torah grants workers produce they handle, even when board is included.
No – once meals are supplied, snacking on untithed produce is forbidden.

title: Finder’s produce on the road
vignette: Someone discovers cut figs lying beside a field’s drying area. May he take and eat them untithed, or must he treat them as someone else’s property?

options.text: Take and eat – they count as ownerless gleanings, exempt from tithes.
Leave (or tithe) – presume an owner; taking without tithing is theft.
